t: Proverbs 21
The*pn king’s heart is a stream of water in the hand of the Lord;*s he*ld turns it wherever he will.
Every*ln way of a man is right in his own eyes, but*ld the Lord*s weighs the heart.
To*ln do righteousness and justice is*ld more acceptable to the Lord*s than sacrifice.
Haughty*ln eyes and a proud heart, the*ld lamp of the wicked, are sin.
The*ln plans of the diligent lead surely to abundance, but*ld everyone who is hasty comes only to poverty.
The*ln getting of treasures by a lying tongue is*ld a fleeting vapor and a snare of death.
The*ln violence of the wicked will sweep them away, because*ld they refuse to do what is just.
The*ln way of the guilty is crooked, but*ld the conduct of the pure is upright.
It*ln is better to live in a corner of the housetop than*ld in a house shared with a quarrelsome wife.
The*ln soul of the wicked desires evil; his*ld neighbor finds no mercy in his eyes.
When*ln a scoffer is punished, the simple becomes wise; when*ld a wise man is instructed, he gains knowledge.
The*ln Righteous One observes the house of the wicked; he*ld throws the wicked down to ruin.
Whoever*ln closes his ear to the cry of the poor will*ld himself call out and not be answered.
A*ln gift in secret averts anger, and*ld a concealed bribe, strong wrath.
When*ln justice is done, it is a joy to the righteous but*ld terror to evildoers.
One*ln who wanders from the way of good sense will*ld rest in the assembly of the dead.
Whoever*ln loves pleasure will be a poor man; he*ld who loves wine and oil will not be rich.
The*ln wicked is a ransom for the righteous, and*ld the traitor for the upright.
It*ln is better to live in a desert land than*ld with a quarrelsome and fretful woman.
Precious*ln treasure and oil are in a wise man’s dwelling, but*ld a foolish man devours it.
Whoever*ln pursues righteousness and kindness will*ld find life, righteousness, and honor.
A*ln wise man scales the city of the mighty and*ld brings down the stronghold in which they trust.
Whoever*ln keeps his mouth and his tongue keeps*ld himself out of trouble.
“Scoffer”*ln is the name of the arrogant, haughty man who*ld acts with arrogant pride.
The*ln desire of the sluggard kills him, for*ld his hands refuse to labor.
All*ln day long he craves and craves, but*ld the righteous gives and does not hold back.
The*ln sacrifice of the wicked is an abomination; how*ld much more when he brings it with evil intent.
A*ln false witness will perish, but*ld the word of a man who hears will endure.
A*ln wicked man puts on a bold face, but*ld the upright gives thought to his ways.
No*ln wisdom, no understanding, no counsel can*ld avail against the Lord.*s
The*ln horse is made ready for the day of battle, but*ld the victory belongs to the Lord.*s
